sourceDesc.bibl: Birth Control Advocate Says Faith and Striving for Ideal Keeps One Young and Beautiful, Denver Post, Aug. 6, 1923, p. 16

headNote.p: Sanger spoke to the press before her talk at the Dever Women's Club luncheon on August 6, 1923. That speech was not found.

docBody.head: BIRTH CONTROL ADVOCATER SAYS FAITH AND STRIVING FOR IDEAL KEEPS ONE YOUNG AND BEAUTIFUL

q.p: To keep young and to remain beautiful, one should acquire a great purpose in life, and establish in the heart a great faith.

This recipe sprang into mind Monday when, after seven years’ absence, Mrs. Margaret Sanger, leader of the National League for Birth Control, came into view younger and lovelier than on her first visit to Denver.

Since her last visit in 1916, Mrs. Sanger has suffered imprisonment many times to prove the faith she holds. She has thru sincerity and persistence drawn a velvet glove on the iron hand of the law in many states; she has, in spite of the refusal of the United States government to vise her passport and over the protest of the Japanese government, entered Japan as an honored guest of its younger statesmen, its thoughtful women and the masses of the people, and women them to her standard.
And now, via Alaska, she has come to Colorado for a real vacation and rest.
Before mentioning the cause near her heart, Mrs. Sanger said she did not wonder that President Harding succumbed to illness on his western tour.

docBody.p: “The president was doubtless very weary when he set out from Washington,” she said. “He had hoped for rest in Alaska. It is a wonderful country, but no place to go for a rest, for there at this time of the year is perpetual daylight. It is daylight, and that gets behind the eyes into the brain and plays havoc with one’s nerves, making sleep impossible to the stranger.”

q.p: Mrs. Sanger insists she sees daylight ahead of her cause. The sort of daylight that does not play havoc with the brain, but sets it to work of the good of humanity.

docBody.p: “When I went to Japan,” she said, “I chose the boat on which the Japanese delegates to the armament congress were returning. I had been refused a vise to my passport to Japan, but I was not discouraged. I met the delegates, and at their request, gave a lecture on war and population. Afterward, they used the wireless to urge the Japanese government to invite me to land and to make arrangements for a series of lectures in Japan. This the government refused to do. Also the American consul refused to make a request that I be permitted to land. However, in Japan, the people are stronger than the government, and the people made it possible for me to go ashore and to lecture.”

As a result, Japan has a league and two birth-control clinics, and statesmen, women, and the masses as represented by labor and trades unions, students, all classes, indeed, are determined that Japan must have fewer and better people.”

“The thoughtful people of Japan realize that it is as foolish to glut the market with a human output as to glut it was an over supply of other produce. Hence their interest in and enthusiasm for the message I carried.”

q.p: The same cordial reception was granted Mrs. Sanger in China and Korea.
No apostle of any cause has paid more dearly for her loyalty than has this gentlewoman with the buoyant voice, lovely eyes and stubborn chin.

As a nurse serving the poor in the tenement districts of New York, a location she selected when she left college, she came to know the miseries resulting from large families in poverty-stricken home. And following the death of a mother who had borne twelve children for whom she had nothing, Mrs. Sanger vowed herself to educating the world as to the injustice of such a state of affairs.
Nine times Mrs. Sanger has heard prison doors swing shut behind her and for thirty days, on one occasion, she remained in jail to prove the constitutionality of the law on which her sentence rested.

Days have changed since she drew that tattered covering over the dead face of the victim to child-bearing in the squalid tenement, and Mrs. Sanger declares her doctrine that a child has at least the right to be well-born is sweeping the earth.

At noon Monday Mrs. Sanger was guest at the Woman’s club luncheon. She lectured later. She also will be a guest of honor at the luncheon to be given Saturday to Miss Alice Paul, vice president of the National Woman’s party.
